Quick Actions for a Seamless Photo Messaging Experience
I love the idea of Signal serving as an alternative to Snapchat for social interactions, but there are a few usability hurdles that make this experience less seamless. One of Snapchat‚Äôs biggest strengths is its intuitive UI shortcuts, which streamline image-based communication. This feature request addresses two specific frustrations I‚Äôve encountered while using Signal in a similar way.

One-Time Image Quick-View
To make viewing one-time images more efficient, I propose an optional setting that allows one-time images to open directly when accessed‚Äîwithout requiring users to first open the chat and then manually open the image. This could be implemented either as a button on the chat list or by automatically opening the image upon entering the chat when a one-time image is available to view.

Additionally, in this quick-view mode, tapping anywhere on the image should dismiss it, rather than requiring users to tap an ‚ÄúX‚Äù icon in the top corner like the current implementation. This would create a more fluid and intuitive experience, similar to how users interact with ephemeral images in other apps.

One-Time Image Quick-Reply
To further improve the fluidity of image-based interactions, I suggest adding a double-tap gesture on the main chat list that directly opens the camera for a quick image reply. This would remove the extra step of opening the chat first before accessing the camera, making rapid back-and-forth image exchanges much smoother.

Conclusion
Both of these enhancements would make Signal a more intuitive and competitive option for users accustomed to Snapchat-style interactions, without disrupting the existing UI. To ensure flexibility, these features could be introduced as optional toggles in the settings, allowing users to enable them based on their preferences.

By implementing these quick actions, Signal could offer a familiar yet more private and secure alternative for users who prioritize fast, image-driven communication.
